titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Smith dined abroad, and Charles passed the day at Countess Colombi’s.— Mrs: Adams in the Evening was quite unwell. Mr Harris sent me a file of the Morning Chronicle from 24. April to 7. May, the perusal of which absorbed almost the whole of my day. The french and German Gazettes communicate gradually and not very distinctly the state of affairs at the armies. The Battle of Lutzen, is claimed as a Victory by both sides— The Russians and Prussians maintained the field, and took a Battery of Cannon— They lost None— But they retreated the next day— The French have crossed the Elbe and threaten Berlin— The situation of things is critical in the highest degree.

2. Mr Harris called upon me this morning with an application from the Mates of the American Vessels at Cronstadt for Passports, to enable them to go home— I spoke to him also concerning two Sailors who came to me last week, complaining that they had been compelled last Winter, to relinquish their wages, and that their Captains insisted upon paying them off, according to the course of Exchange upon London. I had told them that I did not see how they could now claim a release from the agreement they had signed, but as they had ship’d in Salem, to be paid their wages in Dollars, I thought they had a right to be paid in specie or its real value, and not by a course of Exchange in a depretiated paper.— After dinner I rode out with Charles, to Kammenoi-Ostroff, and the Strogonoff garden, round which we walked. The island looks dull and desolate in comparison with the last and preceding years— The Empress passes this Summer at Czarsko-Zelo where she went yesterday.— The trees are in full foliage, but the air is yet chilling Cold.

3. Took Charles out to walk before breakfast this morning, and again after dinner— It was ascension day by the Julian Calendar which is yet observed here— The Kazan Church being open we went in, and surveyed all the trophies of the present War, there deposited— There are ten or twelve French Imperial Eagles, forty or fifty standards of the French last year’s allies, Marshal Davoust’s truncheon which is preserved in a glass case fixed to the Wall, and the Keys of Dresden, Hamburg, Lubeck, Warsaw, Thorn and Czestochoff suspended by ribbons of the order of St: George over long square pasteboards notifying which place each of the sets of keys belong to— We saw the usual morning exercise of troops before the palace— Mr J. W. Smith called on me this forenoon— He still intends to go in a fortnight; but Mr Calhoun remains here some time longer—
I received letters from Mr Beasley and Mr Fosdick, the first of which gave me the heart-ache. After dinner we walked in the Summer-Garden, where there was much Company. Mr Redwood passed the Evening with us— He told us Mr Fisher was to be married to Miss Gregorofsky to-morrow.

4. The Exhibition of the Pupils at the Engineer school under the direction of General Betancourt was fixed for this day and to-morrow, and Mr Smith and I had received invitations to attend it— We went accordingly—it lasted from 10 O’Clock untill two. After which there was a Collation of which we partook. The examination was similar to that of the last year—confined entirely to the Mathematics— Only one of the five French Officers who had been employed in the Instruction of this school, and whom we saw there last year was now present— The rest have been sent into the Country in consequence of the War. The company which attended was not numerous. Count Maistre was there, and I had some conversation with him— He told me there had been news yesterday first from the Prince of Wurtemberg, who commands the Russian army besieging Dantzig, and afterwards by a Courier from the army, of new and splendid successes against the French—fighting three days successively and the French repulsed upon all Points—something of what the Italians call “strepitoso”— But said the Count, if the French were repulsed, they attacked—then they still have the offensive; and they are advancing— I am afraid there is something behind that they do not tell us.— The Courier brought the report too that the Austrians were just commencing hostilities against the French; but I still doubt it— We had also much talk about Books, and Mathematics, and Monastic Orders and Malthus— A Russian Gentleman, told me he wished to send some verses to Mr Swienin his Countryman in America, and asked me to transmit his letter; which he promised to bring me when ready.— After dinner I rode out with Charles to Chrestofsky— We walked in the Botanical Garden, and from the Summer Garden home— Found Mr Harris here

5. Having been accidentally roused from bed at 3 this morning, I could not sleep again— I rose about 5 and as usual felt the loss of rest in a painful and weary drowsiness the whole day. I took Charles to walk in the morning, and rode out with him after dinner, walked round the Strogonoff Garden, and from the Summer-Garden Bridge home.— I had morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Redwood. Mr Fisher was married yesterday, in both the forms of the Greek and the English Church— Mr Redwood came to ask my further interference in his favour to obtain the remission of a fine for importing certain prohibited articles.— I did not attend this day, the exhibition at the Engineer School.

6. I was called this morning from the breakfast table to receive a Note from Mr Lewis, with the melancholy information which deeply affected me, of Mr Fisher’s sudden death— It happened at 5 O’Clock this Morning—probably by a stroke of Apoplexy— He had been even at the time of his Marriage, and for several days very unwell with a severe and constant head-ache— And the last Night so ill that at about 2 this morning he left his wife, and went into another chamber to avoid disturbing her— Being unable to sleep, about five he went out into his yard, and on his return fell backwards from the steps of his door, where he was shortly after found— Dr: Leighton was called in as soon as possible; but life was irrecoverably gone— Mr Smith called at his house shortly after breakfast, to offer any services in our power— The distress of his wife is inexpressible. They were to have been at a bridal dinner, this day at Mr Venning’s, Fisher’s partner— He was a sweet-tempered and tender hearted man; and of all the Americans whom we have known here, the most strongly attached to us, and most warmly grateful for services that I have had the opportunity of rendering him.— I read prayers for Whitsunday, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Sanctity of the Apostles— These Sermons gradually lose the vivacity, and the peculiarities both good and bad, which are so remarkable in those of the first Volumes. I read the remainder of a letter upon the Geography of the land of Canaan, in father Joly, and wrote a very few lines. After dinner I walked in the Summer-Gardens, alone— There was some Company, but no crowd— Mr Smith called on Mr Harris, where he heard that the strepitose affair of which Count Maistre spoke to me so dubiously, the three days battle, had ended in a total defeat of the combined Russian and Prussian Armies—that the Duke of Vicence had since been at the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters, and that it is expected Count Romanzoff will be called thither in a few days— It is further said that the French are in possession of Hamburg. The Russian and Prussian Head-Quarters were at Löwenberg and Goldberg in Silesia, at both which places we were in our tour through that Country— The Battle was on the 21st. 22d: and 23d: of May.— Mr Etter took leave of me for England.

7. Mr Lewis called upon me this morning, to consult me concerning the arrangements advisable to be taken, with regard to the affairs of Mr Fisher— I advised that they should be cautious to proceed conformably to the laws of the Country, in administering upon his property— It is not yet ascertained whether he has left a Will or not.— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s. The usual diplomatic company were there— Also Admiral Tchitchagoff and a young English or Scotchman Lord Dumfries, a Grandson of the Marquis of Bute, travelling for instruction and pleasure— I spoke to Mr Gourieff the Minister of Finance respecting Mr Redwood’s affair— He made me an apology for its being yet delayed. He said that the business before the Committee of the Council was all filed in a certain order, which it was difficult to disturb; but he had been promised, and would assure me that this matter should be decided to-morrow— I told him that I wished not to be importunate; but that the house which was cautionary for Mr Redwood had last week received a second summons to pay the money, and that I understood when the third summons came the payment could no longer be delayed— He repeated the promise that the matter should be decided to-morrow.— I asked Baron Blome which side his Government was—French or against France— He answered laughing, but evasively.— Aye, said he, ask me that Question—but we shall soon know; it cannot last long—at least we have fired guns against both sides.— I asked him whether the Danes were at Hamburg— No! they had been there and evacuated it, by an order, on Count Bernstorff’s return from England; where they had refused even to listen to his propositions— The Swedes were in possession of Hamburg, which they took two days after it was evacuated by the Danes— The late Battles in Saxony were on the 19th: 20th: and 21st of May; the combined armies were not at-all defeated; but they had merely retreated after them to draw on the French Army, untill Austria should march her troops, which was fixed for the 30th: of May— Napoleon and his army are again in the most imminent danger of having their retreat cut-off— In these last Battles he lost nearly double the number of men, that the combined army did—and prisoners; and Cannon—whereas they lost None— Caulaincourt did come to the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters, but was not received— Count Maistre next to whom I sat at table told me that there had been since this Battle a thousand false reports in Circulation; among others that one of the Russian Regiments had refused to obey his orders to fight— That there was a long letter of eight pages from the Emperor to his Mother, which had been seen by several persons, and even copies of it were circulated— That it gave at large his motives for retreating after the Battle; by Count Wittgenstein’s advice.— That he was fighting for the Cause of Europe; but that he ought not to risk too much the blood of his troops, when such a powerful ally was close at hand to share in the losses and in the struggle— Count Romanzoff asked me if I had received any late dispatches from America— I had not; but had seen in English Newspapers articles stating that Mr Daschkoff had offered the Emperor’s Mediation, at Washington, which was immediately accepted— The Courier of 13 May says the British Government will refuse it. The Count had seen these papers, but said he had received no dispatches from Mr Daschkoff— I observed that from the complexion of the Article in the Courier, it was not very important, when Mr Daschkoff’s Communications might arrive; to which he assented— I had also some conversation with the Marquis de Traversey, who thinks the American and Russian Oak less durable than the English— After returning home I rode out with Charles to Kammenoi-Ostroff.

8. There was a continual rain the greatest part of this day— I walked however before Breakfast, and rode out with Charles to Krasna-Kabak after dinner. On my return home I found Mr Harris who spent the Evening with us untill midnight. He has heard several more of the false and absurd rumours whispered about in consequence of the official silence concerning the last Battle— One was that Wittgenstein had been killed or mortally wounded in it; and that his death is kept a great secret— Another that the Russian army was forced to retreat with such rapidity, that they marched 135 Versts in two days. Both these Reports are stupid falsehoods— The last is an impossibility. The Russian retreat must have been about 100 Versts in four or five days, and that is rapid enough, with an incumbrance of their wounded, and of their Artillery— And there would be no imaginable motive for keeping it secret, if Wittgenstein had been killed or wounded— It is but just now that the real issue of the battle of Lützen is coming to light— The accounts on both sides must be compared to collect the truth— The errors in the French relations are chiefly in the details— Those of the combined armies are in the result— The allies maintained the field on the day of battle— But they retreated the next Morning; and I marvel that they should have thought it an occasion for Te Deums.

9. Mr J. W. Smith called upon me this morning. He has postponed his departure untill the week after next— I returned him the remainder of the Collection of Coins and Medals that he had lent me. At 6 this afternoon I went with Mr Smith and attended the funeral of Mr Fisher— The service was read by Dr Beresford— I followed the procession to the burying yard on the Island; and saw the body deposited in a grave immediately by the side of that of my dear and lamented child. I there saw likewise the
monument over her remains— The inscription upon the Stone is that I had given to Mr Gray, the Clerk of the Church— “Louisa Catherine Adams: born 12. August 1811. died 15 September 1812. aged 13 Months and 3 days.”— I had met at the Church Captain M’Donald, of the British Embassy, who has just returned from Moscow—he went thither intending to go to the Russian Head-Quarters, and thence return to England— But he found it so difficult to proceed that he returned and intends going by a different Route— He says he could not have gone from Moscow without taking horses for two hundred Versts for one stage—the villages in all the neighbourhood round being destroyed; and neither Post-masters nor Post-horses remaining— The Captain had the Courier de Londres of 18 and 21 May, which he lent me, with the request that I would return them to him this Evening— I found in them the French official Reports of the Battle of Lützen, and its consequences untill the 8th: of May, when Napoleon entered Dresden— I also found paragraphs from New-York of 11. April—stating that the American Government were about sending a vessel directly to Russia, with a Minister, to negotiate a Treaty of Peace with an English Minister here. On returning from the Island, I called at the Hotel de l’Europe, where Captain M’Donald lodges, but he was abroad— I met him afterwards walking on the Quay, and on the Boulevard— Mr Smith returned his papers.— When I came home I found Mr Lewis, & Mr Willing, who passed the Evening with us untill Midnight.— Mr Willing has just returned from Moscow. Charles [symbols]

10. Mr Lewis and Mr Wainwright called upon me this morning— Mr Lewis had received letters from England with late intelligence from America. I received myself a letter from Mr Beasley, with a slip from the “Times” of 18 May—containing paragraphs of American news.— I took Charles to walk with me, after dinner, and we visited the St: Isaac, and Cazan Churches—on our return we were overtaken by Mr Harris, who passed the Evening with us. He gave me an Account of a long Conversation which he had this morning, with Admiral Tchitchagoff who gave him freely his opinions respecting the present state of political affairs— The Admiral commanded one of the three armies, which last Winter were to have surrounded and intercepted the Emperor Napoleon, at the passage of the Beresino, on his retreat from Moscow last December— Napoleon passed the Beresino, in presence both of Tchitchagoff’s and of Wittgenstein’s armies, and the Admiral has been much censured for having suffered it— He says that at the utmost he had twelve thousand men, and that Napoleon had more than seventy thousand— He speaks with great contempt of the late field Marshal, Prince Kutuzoff, and of Wittgenstein, and in the most explicit manner declares that for all their successes of the last Winter, the Russians were indebted to Famine and Frost.— Mrs Adams was very unwell.

11. Morning visit from Mr Montréal— Count Romanzoff sent me three National Intelligencers of 2, 6, and 9 March which he has just received from Sweden— Mr Harris also sent me several Morning Chronicles— These Newspapers almost absorbed the day. I have finished the reading of Malthus on Population, and have begun with Jortin’s Remarks on Ecclesiastical History— As the prospect of breaking up my establishment here, and the course of life connected with it approaches and becomes certain, I find comforts and pleasures in it, which while enjoyed constantly I have not estimated as they deserve— The loss of them will be no trifling privation— A still more serious reflection is upon the very little account to which I have turned the leisure I have enjoyed here.

12. I took Charles out to walk with me this Morning.—we were overtaken by a shower.— Countess Colombi paid a morning visit to Mrs Adams, who is recovered again from her indisposition. After dinner I walked again in the Summer Garden— Mr Lewis passed the Evening with us— There are a multitude of rumours about the City— An Austrian Declaration of War against France— The retreat of the French Army back to Dresden— The evacuation of Hamburg by the Swedes— Its occupation by a body of Prussian troops— A declaration of War by Denmark against Sweden, Russia and Prussia— The Battles of 19. 20. and 21. May, in and round Bautzen were nearly as bloody, and as undecisive as that of Lützen— The Russian semi-official accounts acknowledge a retreat on the 21st. and they claim a victory on the 26th: at Heynau in Silesia, of their rear guard over the French advanced guard— The subsequent retreat of the French was occasioned by the hostilities commenced or declared of Austria.

13. Trinity Sunday, according to the Gregorian Calendar, and Pentecost or Whitsunday according to the Greek Church. I read prayers for the former, and Sterne’s Sermon upon Penance— I endeavoured also but without success to read further in the Geographie sacree of Joly— I sleep so little in the Night, that I find it absolutely impossible to read in the day time— It is the torture of Tantalus; I threw myself for an hour on the bed, before dinner, but could not sleep— After dinner I went with Mr Smith and Charles to the Catherinenhoff procession of Carriages.— The weather was fine, but the number of Carriages less than I have ever seen on the like
occasion.— The Austrian Declaration of War against France is confirmed, and the retreat of the French army back to Dresden, in consequence of it. Nothing has however yet been officially published on the subject.

14. Morning visit from Mr Harris who had been yesterday to Pavlofsky, where he had heard the same account of the Austrian Declaration, and of the retreat of the French army to Dresden— I walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens— The crowd of People was greater than I ever met there, but very few of the women in the National dresses.— I walked untill past 9 in the Evening and when I left the Garden the crowd was scarcely diminished at-all.— I received this morning from Count Romanzoff a Note, requesting me to call upon him to-morrow at Noon— Settled part of my Monthly Accounts.

15. At noon I called upon Count Romanzoff, according to his appointment. He told me he had received dispatches from Mr Daschkoff, in answer, to the Emperor’s proposal of mediation, which he said appeared to have been completely successful. He then shewed me the copy of Mr Monroe’s Answer to the proposal, as made by Mr Daschkoff— It is dated 11. March, and in very handsome terms accepts the Mediation— It says that further arrangements will shortly be made to carry the acceptance into effect, of which he shall be duly informed— The Count added that Mr Daschkoff informed him he should write him more at large as soon as possible. The Count said he was gratified that this measure had been so received by the United States, though from the manner in which it appeared to be considered in England, he could not flatter himself that it would have any further immediate effect— I said that my own expectations were the same; that by the manner in which it is considered by the Newspapers of all the great parties in England I saw no prospect of its acceptance there. The Courier, a ministerial Paper, had declared itself sure that it would be refused— The Times, a Wellesley and Canning Paper had expressed its regret, at the interest taken by the Emperor, in this Mediation, and its reluctance at the Negotiation’s taking this turn— I had a private letter also mentioning that such was the general Sentiment of all parties in England— I regretted very much that this should be the result, but I was extremely gratified that the measure had been proposed, and at the frankness and readiness with which it had been accepted by my own Government—inasmuch as it had given them an opportunity to manifest to the Emperor and to the world their readiness and even eagerness for Peace; as well as the falsehood of what our enemies were taking such pains to propagate throughout the world; that we acted under the influence of France. The Count replied that he did not expect the Mediation would be directly refused by the British Government— It would cause some embarrassment to the Ministry. By a refusal they would incur a responsibility which they might hereafter find troublesome— But he believed they would give an evasive Answer, and renew the pretence that we were in subserviency to France— He nevertheless hoped that the measure would at a future day not be without its good effects.— He asked me if I had any later Accounts from America, and what was the state of the War— I had no accounts but such as came by the English Gazettes— I mentioned the Bombardment of Lewistown; and the Report of the destruction of Norfolk— The Application by Mr Daschkoff’s Secretary to the British Admiral for a Cartel for a vessel to come here, dispatched by the Government of the United States, and the Report of Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard being destined to come out as Commissioners, of the accuracy of which I had my doubts— I presumed a Commission would be appointed; but I questioned whether they would be the men— Mr Gallatin could not easily be spared, and he and Mr Bayard were so opposite to each other in our politics that I thought it doubtful whether they would be joined in one Commission— The Count said that in a Government like ours that might be the very reason for joining them; so that the great opposing interests might be all represented. I admitted this, but thought it more likely to give rise to the report than to the reality.— He said he should this Evening write to the Emperor, and make him his Report of the Dispatch from Mr Daschkoff—he asked me therefore to send him the English Paper in which I had seen the Article concerning Messrs. Gallatin and Bayard: I accordingly sent him the slip of the Times of 18 May which I received from Mr Beasley.— I had some further conversation with the Count upon other subjects— I told him I had seen in the National Intelligencers that he had lent me, Mr Barlow’s Correspondence with the Duke of Bassano, concerning the invitation to Wilna; and Mr Barlow’s Account of it to the American Secretary of State— I had been happy to observe Mr Barlow’s remark, that if there were any other motives than those of treating concerning our Commerce, and our indemnities, he should know what answer to give— As it so fully confirmed the assurances that I had given to the Count on that occasion— He said he had noticed it in the Correspondence, and had always been fully convinced it was so— He asked me whether I had received an answer, concerning the papers of the Russian Embassy at Paris, of which he had spoken to me. I said I lamented that hitherto all my efforts to obtain an answer from Paris had been unsuccessful— That the person
whom I had dispatched as a Courier had been very long in reaching Vienna— That he had even met with some obstructions and detentions on the road in Russia, owing I presumed to the peculiar situation of that part of the Country, at this time— That on his arrival at Vienna, he had found himself unexpectedly detained there; and had forwarded by mail, one of the two letters I had given him for Paris— This letter was in cypher, and I had authorized him in case he should himself be detained to forward it by Post— It has been received, and yesterday came to me an answer saying that they have no key to the cypher, and cannot read it— I had foreseen that Mr Barlow might not have the key to my cypher, which had been with his predecessor, and had therefore given Mr Delprat a duplicate, without cypher, to be delivered only by himself; and in consequence of his detention this letter had not been received. I had afterwards written again and sent my letter to be forwarded from Copenhagen— I had an answer to that also saying that the Communication between Copenhagen and France was interrupted, and my letter could not be transmitted— Then I had written a third time and dispatched my letter to be forwarded from Hamburg— But the bearer of it, who was going to England, on reaching Berlin found it dangerous to proceed to Hamburg; and had taken the way through Stralsund and Gothenburg— The Count observed that the Communication between Copenhagen and France he supposed was now restored and my letter sent through that channel might now reach its destination— I said I could not yet discover what the position of Denmark was, and of which side she was to be considered— He hesitated a little, and then said he believed Denmark would finally be fixed, as the friend of France in this War— That it seemed so since the positive refusal to hear Count Bernstorff in England, and his return home— It could not be otherwise after that— Though now, added he, the Gazettes say, that the English Government have sent General Hope to Copenhagen.— There is said the Count, a want of combination in some of the proceedings— I had made dispositions which I hoped and yet believe might have secured Denmark to our Cause— But I have been disappointed— I said that the failure of Denmark might be of less importance since the Declaration of Austria, and the subsequent retreat of the French army— He said that he knew nothing of the Austrian Declaration, and did not believe there was sufficient Evidence that the French army had retreated— It had been said he had received an Estafette with the Austrian Declaration; which was not true— The letters from the Army, and even from the Emperor, speak of it as being confidently expected, and that very shortly. Days had even been fixed upon which the Austrians were to have commenced their hostilities—first the 15th: and afterwards the 18th: of May— Both those days however had passed and they had not commenced— The Emperor had not written to him these fifteen days; the co-operation of Austria was promised as a certainty; but there is yet no Account of its having taken effect.— As to the Accounts of the retreat of the French army, they were from Berlin; where they had been excessively and needlessly alarmed, and where they had published every thing true or false that could tend to quiet the alarms of the People— He did not mean to say that there had been no danger to Berlin— Its danger was immense; but not exactly for that week— What motive could the Emperor Napoleon have for going to Berlin, while he had the combined army in presence before him?— But if he can oblige us to cross the Oder, what can hinder him afterwards from going to Berlin just when he pleases? I said that the possession of great Cities, always had on the popular sentiment a more powerful impression than it deserved. There was hardly a Capital in Europe, but had been taken and retaken time after time. People seemed to think it was putting an end to the War; but it scarcely ever had been so.— The Count said that Governments were apt to comply too much with this popular panic on the occupation of great Cities.— Napoleon however paid very little attention to it.— He followed his own course, and let people clamour to their hearts Content— He knew that all such piaulement, signified nothing at all in the course of Events— And it reminded him of a saying of his father’s—Marshal Romanzoff— In the midst of a great Battle some Soldier in a moment of particular danger had loudly exclaimed to him “I will die with you”— Upon which the Marshal instantly answered as loudly—“Away! go and die with whom you will! I want none but such as will live with me!” a sentiment said the Count, which I think as judicious as it was well-timed.— The Count appeared at once inclined to be communicative, and restrained by motives of Prudence from speaking out freely, and I forbore to press him upon topics, with which I had no immediate concern— He asked whether I had any news as to the state of our War with England— I mentioned the destruction of Lewistown; the reported Bombardment of Norfolk, and the capture of the Peacock, by the Hornet— He said that by the late English Newspapers that he had seen there appeared to be a most extraordinary and wonderful stagnation of every thing of general interest.— The Princess of Wales’s Virtue and the Cossack, seemed to have absorbed all
the contemplations of the English Nation— He is evidently not satisfied with the course which things are taking, though he speaks with great caution and reserve— After dinner I walked round the Fontanka, and through the Summer-gardens. Mr Harris spent the Evening with us. Charles was unwell, and had this day no lesson.

16. We had two heavy thunder-showers; one this morning and the other in the Evening— I afterwards rode out with Charles to Kammenoi-Ostrof and Chrestofsky.— Countess Colombi and her Sister Clementine, spent the Evening with our Ladies— I found myself much affected by the weather; and I believe Charles is still more so.— This day the rumours afloat are, that the French are in possession of Hamburg and of Breslau— The official silence still continues.— I am now reading Jortin’s Remarks upon Ecclesiastical History— They are rather more desultory than exactly suits my taste— They start from subject to subject with an abruptness which disconcerts me— They are a sort of emptied Port-Folio— But there is evidently much very curious matter in them; and there is vivacity as well as erudition in the style.

17. We all went at Noon to the warehouse of Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner near the Exchange and saw the Statue of Napoleon, said to be the work of Canova— It belonged to the City of Hamburg, to which it is said he had presented it to be placed in the City Hall. When Coll: Tettenborn entered Hamburg, it was given to him, or he took it, by the right of Conquest, and made a present of it to Count Wittgenstein, his Commander. The Count directed it to be sent from Hamburg to Lubeck; and thence by water to this City; where it arrived lately, consigned to Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner.— It is a pedestrian Statue of white Marble about seven feet high. In the Roman Imperial garb— The face is well executed, and said to be a strong but flattered likeness— Mr Lewis called on me this morning, and was here again in the Evening— The appointment of Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard to come to Russia upon the business of the Mediation is announced in the National Intelligencer— They were to sail from Philadelphia, about the first of May— Mr Forbes also passed the latter part of the Evening here, untill Midnight.

18. Mr Harris called on me this day, and having just been informed that a ship of the line was to be launched from the Admiralty-Yard, proposed to us to go and see it— We all went, and got to the Yard just at the moment when the Posts were struck away from the ways— The railing at the side of the ways broke down, and the ground sunk two or three feet immediately after the ship went off. Mrs Adams and Charles were both at the railing, and in great danger from this accident. Several persons were thrown over and much hurt— The ship is to carry 74 guns, and is called the Neptunus— After dinner I rode out with Mrs. Adams and Charles; we looked over the House and Garden just beyond the Peterhoff gate; belonging to Mr Bergien, and formerly occupied by Count Bussche. I afterwards walked, and met Mr Harris who came home with us and spent part of the Evening here— He at length sent me the translations, French, German and Russian, for which I have been so long waiting.— There is a multitude of Reports and Rumours in Circulation— That of an Armistice is confidently asserted, though quite contradictory to every thing published in the Official Gazettes.

19. Morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr J. W. Smith, who has postponed his departure untill next Saturday— Mr Tilden goes with him— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff requesting to see him, and received an Answer; that he was stepping into his Carriage to go to Czarsko-Selo and Pavlofsky; whence he is to return on Tuesday—that he will see me Wednesday Morning.— After dinner I rode out with Mrs Adams and Charles to Catherinenhoff, where we walked.

20. I have had at length one or two Nights of rest, and this morning rose little before 8— The loss of sleep which I have so long been suffering has affected seriously my health, my spirits and what is more important my capacity of application and of action— I read prayers for the first Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Sermon, upon Enthusiasm; against the Methodists. I also read a few pages in the Geographie sacrée with inspection of the map— It is essential for understanding much of the historical part of the Bible— After dinner I walked with the Ladies and Charles, and afterwards alone in the Summer Gardens, there was a great crowd of People; but almost entirely Russians of the lower classes— Numbers of the women were in the national dresses— I went into the Cazan Church where preparations are making to celebrate the obsequies of Prince Kutuzoff— I went up and examined nearly the Image of the Virgin of Cazan, which they consider as wonder-working— It is a wretched old daubing, not fit for a Sign-post, but the head-dress around it is rich with diamonds and other precious stones. There are a multitude of other paintings—of Angels; Evangelists, Bishops, &c—some of them well executed— Saw the Sun-Set. [symbols]

21. The day of the Summer Solstice; cold and rainy with little interruption the whole day— I only found an opportunity to walk to the Summer-gardens before dinner; and after dinner we rode over to the Island of Petersburg— Mr Smith dined abroad— I received letters from Mr Beasley, Mr Speyer and Mr Fosdick— Mr Beasley enclosed the National Intelligencer of 15 April announcing the appointment of Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard as Commissioners with me, upon the Russian offer of Mediation, and that they were to sail in about ten days.

22. I received this morning a Note from Count Romanzoff, requesting me to call upon him at 1. O’Clock afternoon, which I did. I took with me the French Translation of the two Papers containing the Manifesto on our Declaration of War against Britain; which are to be published— I explained to him the reason why the two pieces were to be taken as comprizing the single Manifesto— He said they should be published—that he had written to the Emperor, charging himself with the wrong of having permitted the publication of the Commentary, which had accompanied the English Manifesto, in the Russian and German Gazettes, and informing him that he had promised me the American Manifesto, without Commentary should be published in the same papers.— I told him I should send him the Russian and German Translations when they should be completed— I also shewed him and left with him the National Intelligencer, containing the Article relative to the Appointment of Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard, which I received yesterday;—observing that he had judged more correctly than I had on the probability of this fact— He said that he was very sorry to say he had received since he saw me further dispatches from Count Lieven, stating that the British Government with many very friendly and polite assurances that there was no Mediation which they should so readily and cheerfully accept as that of the Emperor of Russia, had however stated that their differences with the United States of America, involving certain principles of the internal Government of England, were of a Nature which they did not think suitable to be settled by a Mediation— I said this was no more than I had expected— That I much regretted the failure of this new attempt at Negotiation, but that I was happy the solemnity which the President had given to the acceptance of the Emperor’s offer, by the appointment of two persons so highly distinguished in our Country, would at least manifest the sense which he entertained of the Emperor’s friendly sentiments and proposal, as well as the constant desire of the American Government for Peace— He said it was the light in which he had already represented it to the Emperor, and it would now be for consideration, whether after the step thus taken by the American Government, it would not be advisable to renew the proposition to Great-Britain; upon which he should write to the Emperor. Perhaps it might be proper not to be discouraged by the ill-success of the first Advances.— After considerations might produce more pacific dispositions in the British Government— Unexpected things were happening every day; and in our own affairs said the Count, a very general report prevails that an armistice has taken place— I said I had for the last four or five days heard rumours of that sort in circulation, and had intended to ask him, if I might without indiscretion, whether they were true— He said they were. He had no doubt they were. He had received no official account of it— The Emperor had not written to him— The multitude of his occupations sufficiently explained this— The Emperor, did every thing himself— He was Emperor, Commander in Chief, Quarter-Master, and in short superintended every thing— It was therefore perfectly natural that he had not found time to write to him; and from motives of delicacy, he did not permit any other person to write to him; so that he had received nothing official on this subject. But there were letters from the army which ascertained the fact, and indeed Count Löwenhielm had received it officially from the Prince Royal of Sweden to whom it had been communicated.— There was also an Article in the Berlin Gazette of 8 June, mentioning that a Russian and a French Officer had passed through that City from the respective Head-Quarters bound to Hamburg—they were doubtless sent to extend the armistice to the troops in that quarter— I asked him whether the Prince of Sweden and his troops were included in the armistice— He supposed so—for what length of time was it?—for five or six weeks.— I had heard it was to the 20th: of July— It must be about that— I had seen also a proposal mentioned for a Congress at Prague— Yes, there was such a proposal, and the United States are expressly named among the powers to be invited to it— But in this universal state of War, partial Peaces seem hardly (said he) to be an adequate remedy— The Emperor Napoleon proposed the armistice— I suppose that it was hunger that led to the proposal— He wanted it for a longer time, but the five or six weeks was all that they could agree upon—that will bring them to the new harvest— I said
I hoped it would bring them at least to the prospect of Peace— The Count did not appear to expect it.— I then mentioned the expectation I had of the arrival of my new Colleagues at Cronstadt; which might be from hour to hour— And asked if they could be presented to the Empresses in the Emperor’s absence— He said he believed they might to the Empress Mother, who had a Court of her own and received Company at Pavlofsky— But the Empress Elizabeth was at Czarsko-Selo quite in retirement, and saw nobody— I asked if it would be necessary to give any order that they might not be delayed at Cronstadt. He said that an order might be necessary for the admission of their baggage; and if I would write him a couple of lines of a note, mentioning my expectation of their arrival, he would take upon himself the charge to make all the proper arrangements.— I told him that I presumed the President of the United States had not made these Appointments without being aware that the British Government might reject the Mediation, and thus leave us nothing to do. I concluded therefore that he had a second object in sending them both—that one of them was destined to succeed me here, and that the other would probably have another destination— He said, perhaps to France?— I said I could not tell—it was merely my conjecture— He replied that if it was to France, he should have no objection— He thought the maxim of Cato the Censor very good in Politics; though he detested it in every thing else— He meant the rule of always hating your Enemy, as if he was one day to be your friend; and loving your friend as if he might one day be your enemy.— He added some expressions of civility upon the information that I expected to have a successor, and to leave this Country; with much regret that I should not have the opportunity of taking a part in the Negotiation for Peace— I thanked him for his good opinion, and assured him that nothing could be so gratifying to my own wishes, as to have the means of contributing to produce Peace; but that while England should refuse to treat I must acquiesce in the consequences, and give up the hope of labouring in so good a work— I was with the Count about half an hour.— Mr Harris had paid me a morning visit just before I went out— After dinner I called at General Aminoff’s lodgings to thank him for his present of a Medal; but he left the City yesterday morning for Sweaborg, and will be absent three or four Months. I walked in the Summer-Gardens, and rode with Mrs: Adams and Charles to the Apothecary’s Island.— Received an invitation from Princess Golenishtcheff Kutuzoff Smolensky, to attend the funeral service for her husband the late Field-Marshal, at the Cazan Cathedral, Friday-Morning; and a notice from the Grand-Master of the Ceremony Narishkin, that an Apartment for the Corps Diplomatique, would be reserved at Countess Strogonoff’s house, to see the funeral procession, at three O’Clock P.M. to-morrow.

23. i went with Mr Smith at 3 O’Clock this afternoon to Count Strogonoff’s house, to see the funeral procession— Most of the Members of the Diplomatic Corps, were there— The Duke of Serra Capriola, and Baron Blome were absent— We waited from 3 untill near 7 in the Evening before the Procession went by. Count Löwenhielm went away between 4 and 5. taking with him Mr Forbes, who was to go as his Courier, and from his house after dinner— The Count himself by orders from his Government is going to the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters. The procession was as magnificent as any thing of the kind I had ever seen. The body had been embalmed at Bunzlau, and transported to the Monastery of St: Serge at Strelna, about ten Miles from the City— At 11 this Morning it was placed on a Car and drawn by horses to the Tarakanoffka river, the bounds of the City, beyond the Peterhoff gate— There the procession was formed; the Car, bearing the Coffin under a crimson velvet Canopy, was drawn by the People— The nobility, the Clergy, the high Civil and military authorities and the merchants of the City (bearded Russians) marched in the procession, which was closed by detachments of troops, about 5000 infantry and 1000 cavalry. The body was deposited on the Catafalque in the Cazan Church— The Princess Amelia of Baden had come from Czarsko-Zelo to see the procession, but went away about half an hour before it passed by. We came home to dinner just at 7. Mr Redwood and Mr Tilden passed the Evening with us.

24. i had a long morning visit from Mr Laval, who is to set out next week on his second attempt to go to England. He is very doubtful whether the Armistice will lead to a Negotiation for peace— He rather thinks it will be employed in bidding, and counterbidding for the Alliance of Austria, for which he supposes the allies have a much higher offer to make than France. I am not altogether of that opinion— There is a proclamation of the king of Prussia announcing the armistice, but it has not yet been officially declared here— Mr Montreal was also here this morning— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us— I wrote to Count Romanzoff and Count Löwenhielm, for Passports for Messrs: J. W. Smith and Tilden, and received them.— Received a letter from Mr Speyer at Stockholm, with an extract of an official Article in the Gazette of that City of 15 June—a sort of bulletin from the Prince Royal at Stralsund— After dinner Mrs Adams and Charles went with me to the Cazan Church, where we
saw the preparations for the funeral Ceremony at the interment of Prince Kutuzoff Smolensky— The Catafalque is in the centre of the Church immediately under the Dome. A Cubic Basis, and about twelve feet high with steps to ascend at the four Corners. There is an Arch in the middle of it high enough for a man to pass through; the Coffin is placed at the summit, on bars over a cavity large enough to let it down by machinery— The Coffin is said to weigh 60 Poods, about a Ton, avoirdupois. It is surrounded by Trophies—French Eagles and Standards, and Bashaw’s Horse-Tails. all round the basis are rows of large tapers to be lighted. The whole fabric which is of painted wood appears to be rested on four fluted Corinthian pillars at the four Corners— A figure of Fame, or of an Angel with a crown of laurel in one hand hovers over the coffin, suspended by a Rope from the summit of the Dome. On the two sides of the catafalque are ranged stools with velvet Cushions on each of which is placed some mark of dignity which he had acquired. The sword, the Marshal’s Truncheon, the Orders of the Prussian Black and Red Eagles, the Austrian order of Maria Theresa, and the Russian Orders of St: Andrew, St: Alexander Nevsky, St: George of the first-Class, St. Ann, and St: Wlodimir— The Church was much crowded, but by the civility of the Master of the Police, General Gorgoly, we saw every thing— The Marshal’s Truncheon and Sword-hilt are superbly studded with Diamonds; and the Eagle and Star of the Order of St: Andrew are entirely of diamonds— But the highest distinction of all is the Order of St: George of the first Class, a plain Cross suspended by a Black and yellow Ribbon— He was the only person in the Empire who possessed it— The Emperor himself hung it on his Neck, on arriving at Wilna last December.— It is reserved exclusively for Commanders in Chief of Armies; and for atchievements of the most signal importance—

25. I went with Mr Smith to the Cazan Cathedral Church, very shortly after ten this Morning, but we found that the Ceremony had already begun— It continued untill half past one, nearly four hours, during the whole of which we were standing— The Ceremony appeared in some particulars different from those of the same kind I had attended before, but being totally ignorant of the language in which it was performed, I could not understand the difference— The Metropolitan Ambrose officiated, and the Archimandrite Philarete preached the Sermon, which was said to be in the highest style of Eloquence and Pathos.— The manner was temperate, not to say cold. The discourse about half an hour long.— The Prince is buried in the body of the Church, by the side of one of the Walls; under a Picture representing the deliverance of Moscow— His nephew Admiral Kutuzoff was seized with a violent and very distressing fit of the asthma, immediately after performing the last act of duty to the Corpse, as usual at their interments— It was found necessary to take him out of the Church.— Most of the Corps Diplomatique was there— I asked Baron Blome, if I could find him at home, to have some conversation with him. He said he would call upon me.— Count Löwenhielm was also there— Not yet gone— Immediately after the Ceremony, we went and left Cards at the Princess’s house, according to the usage. Mr J. W. Smith was here this morning while I was absent— I met Mr Harris, walking, after dinner— He came home and spent the Evening with us.

26. The day was so cold that in one of our Apartments we had a fire; and heavy rain great part of the day— Mr J. W. Smith came in the morning and I gave him his Passports and my letters and dispatches. At 6 in the Evening he called again, and I gave him the two remaining packets of dispatches for the Secretary of State— He and Mr Tilden left the City this Evening— I read part of the preface to the Abbé Delille’s translation of the Eneid— He defends his author upon a point, on which he has generally been discredited—the delineation of Character.

27. Read prayers for the Second Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Eternal Advantages of Religion— It appears to be a second part, or rather in substance a repetition of that upon time and chance— I likewise read a few pages in the Geographie sacrée; but was obliged to lay it aside; being unwell with a severe Cold— Baron Blome called upon me according to his promise, and had a long Conversation with me upon political affairs— He thinks there will be no Peace between Russia and France, and excepting with relation to his own Government he knows Nothing but what is nearly public— He says Denmark has been forced into a new Alliance with France, when she would have been glad to join in the Alliance against her— That there is neither harmony nor Combination in the views or operations of the Allies— That Russia and England are not agreed—that the British Ministry sent here “un imbecille,[”] for their Ambassador— That the Prince Royal of Sweden, is making dupes of them all— That they are paying him with the design that he should attack France, against which he will never fire a musket, and that he intends to make them pay him richly for despoiling and plundering Denmark, and all the time be clamorous at their non-fulfilment of their Treaties with him. That England had stipulated the payment of the subsidy should not commence untill he had landed in Pomerania; but that when Count Bernstorff went to England, the Crown Prince sent word that he would not embark for Pomerania, unless Bernstorff was rejected without a hearing— That he had always protested to the Danish Chargé d’Affairs at Stockholm that Denmark should be amply indemnified, more than indemnified for Norway. He had offered the Hanseatic Cities, and even
Holland—any thing—any where—pushing the hypocrisy to shedding of tears, but well knowing that all his promises of indemnity were mere words, signifying nothing.— The Emperor Alexander had sent Prince Dolgorucki to Copenhagen— The Prince, for the sake of conciliating Denmark had gone perhaps a little further than was warranted by his instructions— He had declared that Russia had not positively guaranteed Norway to Sweden; but only on the condition that Denmark should be indemnified for the cession— Upon that basis, the king of Denmark had consented to treat; but when the Swedish Crown Prince heard what Dolgorucki had done, he immediately insisted that it should be disavowed and that he should be recalled, which was done— That after all this Denmark had renewed her Negotiations with France— There had been actual hostilities, between the Danes at Hamburg and the French— The king had as a matter of form disavowed their occupation of that City— Napoleon had demanded that the commanding Officer should be dismissed and punished—the king had removed him from that command, but would not disgrace him— All this France knew was mere form— There was no duplicity in the conduct of Denmark— He was sure that in substance they had explicitly avowed to France every thing they had done; which was fully justified by the Circumstances; and there was not a word of truth in the Story, the Crown Prince had published at Stralsund, that while President Kaas, was treating with D’Avoust at Haarburg, he sent a verbal message to General Tettenborn at Hamburg that the king of Denmark was ready to join the coalition with 25000 men against France.— Blome added that he had no late information from his Government— His Communications were very much interrupted— He could seldom write but through Sweden, and throughout the whole of last Winter, not one dispatch between him and his Government had been suffered to pass— Every one of them had been intercepted— At this outrage, as at many others, Denmark to avoid bringing things to extremities had shut her eyes— Count Romanzoff had letters from Lisakewitz to the 8th. and had shewn him Thornton’s Note to Mr Rosenkrantz, when the “troupeau de Ministres” arrived off Copenhagen, from Stralsund; with Rosenkrantz’s answer; which was in terms of great moderation— The Danish Government had published them both, and the public Spirit had been excited to the highest indignation by the terms proposed— The public Spirit was the same in Norway, although in the Grand Balliage of Drontheim the famine was so severe that forty persons perished daily with hunger— They were cut off from all supplies; but they only wanted to go and find their granaries in Sweden— The King had sent the heir to the Crown into Norway; but so closely and narrowly was the coast watched that he had been obliged to go over, disguised as a Sailor— Lisakewitz on the 8th: had received no order for his departure, but expected it— Blome himself has received no order for his departure; but Count Löwenhielm, whom he had seen at Countess Tolstoi’s, and who had received a Courier in four or five days from Stockholm had told him he had official advices of the Declaration of Denmark against Russia and Sweden— The object of England, Blome says, in giving Norway to Sweden, is to take Zeeland for herself; but that if Sweden has Norway, England can never keep Zeeland, because the Sound can at all times be passed in spite of any fleet.— He is in great anxiety and alarm; and expects that an attack will immediately be made on the island of Zeeland.— After dinner I rode and walked with Mr Smith and with Charles at Catherinenhoff.

28. Morning visits from Mr Montreal, and Mr Gibson— This Gentleman intends to leave the City in three or four weeks, and I promised to procure a Courier’s Passport for him and to give him dispatches— After dinner I rode out with Charles and walked round the Strogonoff Garden. I walked from the Summer Garden alone home. Met Mr Schulepoff, the under Secretary in the department of foreign Affairs. He told me that Count Romanzoff, immediately after receiving my note, mentioning my expectation of the arrival of Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard, had given official notice of it to the Marquis de Traversey, the Marine Minister, and to Mr Gourieff the Minister of the Finances; so that every arrangement for their arrival, and the landing of their baggage would be made— I also met Captain Bates and Mr: Hurd—the former of whom told me that the English papers of the 8th: contained accounts from Halifax of 3. May—and brought the news, that the Essex Frigate was taken, and that we had suffered another defeat in Canada.— News not the less painful for being expected.

29. i had a morning visit from Mr Harris, and he spent the Evening with us. Took Charles to walk before Breakfast; after dinner I walked in the Summer Gardens alone— Mr Harris sent me English Newspapers; the Morning Chronicle, from 24 to 28 May.— The Russian Military Journal this day published mentions the Armistice concluded 4. June, on the proposition of the French Emperor, and with the concurrence of the Austrian Court, but the Armistice itself has not been published.

30. I took a warm Bath this morning before Breakfast— Mr Redwood called on me, still anxious and uncertain concerning the prosecution for a penalty hanging over him, for an importation of prohibited Articles— I wrote another Note upon the subject to Mr: Gourieff the Minister of Finance.— After my Evening walk I read some pages of Jortin’s Remarks upon Ecclesiastical History; which are loaded with a great multiplicity of Greek and Latin Citations, but are very amusing.— Some of them are rather rank, for the subject, and the author, a Clergyman. On the Apostolical Constitutions, the Jewish Sects of Pharisees, Sadducees and Essenes, and the Sibylline Oracles and verses there is much curious information— Some of the Essenes it says never married because they believed all married women unfaithful— Jortin asks how they could honour their fathers and mothers?— La Harpe has I think a similar observation upon Juvenal’s 6th: Satire— The other day at the Field Marshal’s funeral procession we had this subject discussed between Count Löwenhielm, Count Maistre and the Chevalier Bardaxi— Lowenhielm was remarking the resemblance between Count Maistre and his brother— Bardaxi observed upon it the general resemblance which usually runs through families— Löwenhielm said that when brothers had not the same father this resemblance was very apt to fail, and added that he believed there were few, very few women indeed who did not give their children more than one father— I told him that was only the opinion of a libertine; but as both the other gentlemen fell foul of him, as champions of the sex, I took no further part in the discussion— Löwenhielm had the worst of the argument— But he may have taken his opinion from his own family— He and his brother are supposed to have had two fathers— He bears a very strong and unequivocal resemblance to the nuptial father, my old friend Count Löwenhielm, whom I knew as Swedish Minister at the Hague— His brother has not a feature of that resemblance, and is reputed to be the Son of the present king of Sweden, whom he does resemble. So that it may be his way of honouring his Mother, to consider her frailty as that of the whole sex.

Day. The only difference between this and the preceding Months, is that of keeping later evening and morning hours. We have now frequently American evening visitors untill near Midnight, and I rise accordingly seldom before seven— Sometimes little before Eight.— Charles has this day begun reading the Book of Joshua. He has finished the Pentateuch.— I cannot yet say however that he reads well— His progress in writing and cyphering is yet slower— He writes two Copies every day with me, and twice a week has a writing Master— He has yet scarcely an idea of numeration or of addition— His health is yet feeble.
